options.label: A
options.text: Only the roots of this plant are poisonous

options.label: C
options.text: Atropine is not specific for aconite poisoning

questions.correct_answer: A. Only the roots of this plant are poisonous
questions.explanation:
Species

Aconitum napellus, Aconitum ferox

Synonyms

Monk’s hood, mitha zaher, bish, wolf’s bane, women’s bane, devil’s helmet, or blue rocket

Source
  • All parts of the plant are poisonous (Option A)
  • Root and root tubers are the most potent (often mistaken for horseradish root)
  • Grown in Mountainous areas of the northern hemisphere. Eg. Sub Himalayan range (Option D ruled out)

Active Principles

Aconitine, pseudo-aconitine, indaconitine, picraconitine, aconine.

Mechanism of Action

Affects voltage-sensitive sodium channels, stimulates then paralyzes sensory nerves, secretory nerves, CNS, and myocardium.

Symptoms (by system)
  • GIT: Nausea, vomiting, salivation, abdominal pain, diarrhea, burning/tingling of mouth, tongue, throat, followed by numbness.
  • CVS: Hypotension, AV block, bradycardia, chest pain, ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation, slow/feeble pulse. (Option B ruled out)
  • CNS: Vertigo, restlessness, headache, giddiness.
  • MS: Muscle weakness, twitching, spasms.
  • RS: Slow, labored, shallow breathing.
  • Ocular: Alternating pupil dilation/contraction (hippus), diplopia, impaired vision.
  • Others: Subnormal temperature, cold skin, yellow-green vision, tinnitus, paralysis of facial muscles.
  • Death: Respiratory failure or ventricular fibrillation.

Fatal Dose

Root: 1-2 g

Treatment
  • No specific antidote.
  • Gastric lavage with tannic acid/activated charcoal.
  • Inotropic therapy for hypotension, atropine for bradycardia. (Option C ruled out)
  • Ventricular arrhythmia treated with amiodarone, flecainide; cardiopulmonary bypass for refractory cases.

Medico-legal Aspects
  • Ideal homicidal poison: cheap, easily available, small lethal dose, short fatal period, difficult to detect postmortem.
  • Accidental poisoning: mistaken for horseradish

questions.text: Paradoxical undressing is seen in :
questions.explanation:
Hypothermia

Definition

Core temperature below 36°C (96.8°F)

Signs
  • Disorientation
  • Dulling of consciousness
  • Loss of reflex
  • Fall in respiration, heart rate, and blood pressure
  • Red patches and pallor of the skin
  • Edema of the face
  • Stiffness of neck muscles

Autopsy findings
  • Patches of pink to brownish-pink discoloration
  • Postmortem staining: Pink/bright red
  • Cyanosis or pallor in extremities ("white deaths")
  • Edema of feet and blistering of skin
  • Stomach: Wischnewsky spots-brownish black colored gastric mucosal ulcers
  • Viscera-congested, hemorrhagic

Phenomena seen in hypothermia victims

  • Paradoxical undressing- found undressed due to disorientation which increases heat loss (mistaken for evidence of sexual assault or homicide)
  • ‘Hide and die' syndrome- found in unusual locations resembling an attempt to "hide" or create a protective environment due to mental confusion and a possible hibernation reflex (confused with signs of homicide or robbery)
  • Chilblain (Erythema Pernio)- red, itching skin lesions typically found on extremities due to cold exposure, often accompanied by edema and blistering.

Identify the injury the image below :
questions.explanation:
Scratch Abrasion (Linear Abrasion)

Grazed Abrasion (Sliding Abrasion)

Mechanism: Caused by tangential (side-to-side) force, producing a long and narrow abrasion.

Features: Linear in nature, with length being more significant than width.

Examples: Fingernail abrasion, thorn abrasion, and pin abrasion.


 

Mechanism: Occurs when skin slides over a rough surface, resulting in superficial scrapes.

Also Known As: Grinding abrasion, gravel rash, brush-burn.

Features: Seen in road traffic accidents or falls, especially on exposed areas like knees or elbows.

Imprint Abrasion (Patterned Abrasion)

Pressure Abrasion (Crushing Abrasion)

Mechanism: Results from compressive force applied perpendicular to the skin, leaving a distinct pattern of the object.

Also Known As Impact abrasion, contact abrasion, patterned abrasion.

Examples: Tyre marks, bite marks

 

Mechanism: Caused by a continuous vertical force applied to the skin, crushing the epidermis.

Features: Deeper skin injuries are often seen with prolonged pressure, potentially leading to necrosis.

Examples: Ligature marks in hanging or strangulation

Multiple Lines
  • Indicate the endpoint of the abrasion.
  • Reflect the direction of the applied force.

Uneven and Longitudinal Lines
  • Show irregularity at the end of the abrasion.
  • Suggest pulling or scraping of the skin.

Heaped-up or Aggregated Lines
  • Also known as Epithelial tags (Terminal tags)
  • Skin tissues dragged opposite to the force direction.
  • Point toward the end of the abrasion, indicating the force direction
  • (e.g., tags heaped at the right end, if the force was left to right).

Name the type of skull fracture.
questions.explanation:
Motorcyclist Fracture (Hinge Fracture)

(Option B)

Ring Fracture

(Option D ruled out)
  • Transverse fracture at the skull base, splitting it and creating a "hinge" - nodding face sign.
  • It extends from one petrous ridge across the sella turcica to the other petrous ridge.
  • Encircles the foramen magnum at the skull base.
  • Runs from the sella turcica to the petrous ridges and posterior fossa.
  • It can extend to the middle ear and roof of the nose.

Often caused by side impacts.


 

Caused by:

  • Falls landing on feet/buttocks (force transmitted through the spine).
  • Heavy blows to the top of the skull/ vertex.
  • Twisting of the head on the spine.
  • Blows to the occiput or chin.

Hinge fracture

Ring fracture

Depressed Fracture (Option A ruled out)
  • Occurs when a fragment of the skull is pushed inward towards the brain.
  • Caused by blows from heavy objects with a small surface (e.g., hammers, bricks).
  • The shape of the depressed area may resemble the object that caused the injury.

Variants:

  • Elevated Fracture: One end of the fractured fragment is raised above the skull, while the other is pushed inward. Caused by sharp objects like an axe.
  • Pond Fracture: Seen in infants, this smooth depression occurs without a fracture line, resembling a dent in a ping-pong ball. Caused by obstetrics forceps blade.(Option C ruled out)

Depressed fracture

questions.text: A registered medical practitioner is requested by a survivor of sexual violence to examine her. Within what time must the practitioner take a vaginal swab to look for the presence of spermatozoa?

During the visit to the outpatient department, a female patient aged 18 years was examined. The genital examination disclosed the following observations. These observations suggest: 1. Labia majora - separated 2. Labia minora - flabby 3. Fourchette tear present 4. Roomy vagina seen with intact hymen
questions.explanation:
Category

True Virgin

(Option A ruled out)

False Virgin

Genital Signs
  • Intact, rigid, inelastic hymen; admits only a fingertip, causing pain.
  • Thick, fleshy labia majora that close the vaginal orifice; small, pink labia minora covered by labia majora.
  • Narrow vagina with prominent rugae; full finger cannot be admitted.
  • Present fossa navicularis, intact fourchette, narrow vestibule, small clitoris, intact posterior commissure.
  • Intact hymen that may be loose, elastic, or thick; admits two fingers easily.
  • Less fleshy labia majora; vaginal orifice may be visible; enlarged, pigmented labia minora.
  • Roomy vagina with less prominent rugae; full finger can be admitted.
  • Disappearance of fossa navicularis; torn and healed fourchette; wider vestibule; enlarged clitoris; possibly torn posterior commissure.

Extra-Genital Signs

Small, hemispherical, firm breasts; pink areola.

Larger, pendulous, flabby breasts; pigmented areola.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for graphical representation in flow cytometry analysis?
Identify the following post mortem change:
questions.explanation:
Other Names

Postmortem staining, subcutaneous hypostasis, cadaveric lividity, suggillation, cogitation, vibices, and darkening of death.

Definition

Bluish or purplish-red discoloration caused by the gravitational settling of blood in the toneless capillaries and venules of the dependent parts of the dead body.

Site

Superficial layers of the dermis

Mechanism

Blood in capillaries and venules → Stagnates and sinks in dependent parts due to gravity → Bluish purple discoloration due to deoxy hemoglobin.

Begins

0.5 - 1 hour

Fully Developed

Within 4 hours

Fixation of Livor Mortis

Typically, within 6-12 hours

Confirmation of Fixation

Apply thumb pressure against the skin for a few seconds → Blanching → Livor mortis not fixed.

Primary Lividity

Occurs as lividity reaches maximum intensity between 6 to 12 hours after death.

Secondary Lividity

Shifting of lividity can occur if the body is moved within a few hours after death.

Duration of Persistence

Staining persists until putrefaction begins.

Distribution

Depends on position of the body:

Supine

Appears on the back of neck, entire back, flanks, except areas under pressure (contact pallor).

Prone

Appears on the front part of the body.

Side

Appears on the dependent side.

Head downwards

Appears as a blackened face and neck.

Vertical suspension

Appears on legs and hands (glove and stocking appearance) and external genitalia.

Drowning

Appears on the face, upper chest, hands, lower arms, feet, and calves.

Livor Mortis Absent

  • Excessive blood loss
  • Severe anemia
  • Death from wasting diseases
  • Lobar pneumonia

Medicolegal Importance
  • Helps estimate time of death.
  • Indicates body posture at death.
  • Indicates if the body was moved post-death.
  • Distribution may indicate the cause of death.

Image

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Vulval Cancer

Site
  • Labia majora is the most common (60%).
  • Clitoris 2nd most common (15%).
  • Most common in 50-70 years age group

Presentation
  • Exophytic (outward-growing) and ulcerative (open sore) growth.

Symptom
  • Pruritus (most common): Often associated with an itch-scratch cycle.
  • Cancer cachexia (weight loss and muscle wasting).
  • Cancer pain.

Spread
  • Primarily spreads through the lymphatic system.
  • Vulvar lymphatics cross over at the midline, especially within 2 cm of the midline.
  • The inguinofemoral lymph nodes are the most commonly involved group.
  • Lymph node involvement significantly affects prognosis.

Investigations
  • Excisional biopsy (IOC): For lesions < 1 cm in size. Complete lesion removal and histological assessment, including invasion presence and depth.
  • Incisional biopsy: For lesions ≥ 1 cm in size.
  • Wedge biopsy.
  • Keyes punch biopsy.
  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy: Assess lymph node involvement, particularly the inguinofemoral nodes.

Treatment of Tumor Stages of Vulval Cancer

Stage 1a

  • Wide local excision with a 1-cm margin is performed for the probable cure.

Stage 1b
  • Radical resection of the primary tumor and inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy (LAD).
  • Central lesion: B/L LAD
  • Lateral lesion (> 2 cm from midline): U/L LAD.

Stage II
  • Radical vulvectomy + B/L LAD
  • Positive LN involvement in HPE - Must do pelvic LAD or pelvic LN radiotherapy.

Stage III
  • Radical partial or total vulvectomy and either SLNB or inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy.
  • Postoperative adjuvant radiation (4000-5000 Rads over 5 weeks) directed to both the groins and the pelvis.

Stage IV
  • Treated with chemotherapy or radiotherapy
  • Chemotherapy: 5-FU, mitomycin C
  • Other agents used are Methotrexate, bleomycin, and trastuzumab.

A patient is on phenytoin for a seizure disorder. He was prescribed sucralfate four times a day for peptic ulcer. What should be the minimum duration of time between consumption of these drugs?
questions.explanation:
Ulcer Protective Agents

 

Bismuth

Sucralfate

Properties

Water-soluble, but precipitates when pH <5

Basic aluminium salt of sulfated sucrose. Polymerises at pH <4, forming a sticky gel-like consistency.

Mechanism of Action
  • Increases production of gastric mucosal prostaglandin E, mucus, and bicarbonate.
  • Precipitate mucus glycoproteins and coat the ulcer base.
  • Detach and inhibit Helicobacter pylori directly.
  • Precipitates surface proteins at the ulcer base, creating a physical barrier against acid, pepsin, and bile.
  • Does not neutralise acid but delays gastric emptying.
  • Potentially augments gastric mucosal prostaglandin synthesis for additional protection.

Dosage and Administration

120 mg taken half an hour before the three major meals and at bedtime for 4-8 weeks

1 gram taken on an empty stomach one hour before the three major meals and at bedtime for 4-8 weeks

Side Effects
  • Diarrhoea,
  • Headache,
  • Dizziness,
  • Blackening of the tongue, dentures, and stools
  • Constipation
  • Hypophosphatemia
  • Dry mouth
  • Nausea

Indications
  • gastritis and non-ulcer dyspepsia associated with H. pylori
  • Occasionally used as part of a triple-drug regimen.

Bile reflux, gastritis, and prophylaxis of stress ulcers.

Risperidone

Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic medication that is approved by the FDA for the treatment of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder (both manic and mixed episodes)

Also binds alpha 1 and 2 receptor, and the H1 receptor

FDA approved

  • Maintenance therapy in mania bipolar disorder
  • Management of irritability in autism spectrum disorder

 

Off label uses

  • Management of psychosis in delirium and dementia (Option B)
  • Obsessive-compulsive disorders (Option A)
  • PTSD (Option C)

Adverse effects
  • Hyperprolactinemia
  • Cardiovascular accident
  • Extrapyramidal side effects

options.label: C

questions.correct_answer: B. Half-life remains the sam,e and plasma concentration doubles
questions.explanation:
First-order kinetics

Zero-order kinetics

Description

A constant fraction of the drug is eliminated per unit of time.

A constant amount of the drug is eliminated per unit of time.

Rate of clearance

Constant

More at lower concentrations and less at higher concentrations.

Half-life

Constant

Less at lower concentrations and more at higher concentrations.

Rate of elimination

Proportional to its plasma concentration.

Independent of plasma concentration.

Examples

Most of the drugs.

Alcohol, aspirin, theophylline, tolbutamide, and warfarin.

questions.text: A patient with a history of ischemic stroke was started on clopidogrel. However, she had another stroke after 6 months. Which of the following could be responsible for the failure of clopidogrel in this patient?

Clopidogrel

Clopidogrel is a prodrug that requires activation by CYP2C19 to become an active antiplatelet drug.

Activation 
  • CYP2C19 is an enzyme found in the liver and is responsible for converting clopidogrel into its active form.
  • Certain genetic polymorphisms or drug interactions can lead to reduced activity of CYP2C19, and the activation of clopidogrel may be reduced

Uses 
  • Post Myocardial infarction
  • Post cerebrovascular accidents
  • Peripheral arterial diseases
  • Acute coronary syndrome

Adverse effects
  • Risk of bleeding if used with anticoagulants or antiplatelets
  • Rare - thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura

Enzyme

Substrate

CYP2D6

SSRIs, Opiates, Beta-blockers, tricyclic antidepressants

CYP1A1/2

Theophylline, Paracetamol, caffeine

CYP2E1

Alcohol, halothane, Paracetamol

Clomiphene citrate

It is an unequal mixture of two isomers, Zuculomiphene + Eclomiphen.e

Zuclomiphene
  • The weaker isomer with partial estrogen agonist activity.
  • Non-steroidal compound that blocks the negative inhibitory feedback of estrogens on the hypothalamus (GnRH release) (Option B)
  • Results in sthe urge of gonadotropin, which stimulates ovulation

Enclomiphene
  • The stronger isomer has predominant estrogen antagonist activity.
  • Primarily responsible for the anti-estrogenic effects that stimulate gonadotropin release and induce ovulation.

Action

  • Thinning of the endometrium (Option C)

Uses

  • It can be used along with exogenous Gonadotropin (Option D)

Side effects

Hot flushes and nausea

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of liver cirrhosis presents with abdominal distension and swelling of the lower limbs. What is the preferred diuretic for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Eplerenone

MOA

Mineralocorticoid receptor / Aldosterone antagonist resulting in natriuresis and reducing edema

Uses
  • Primary hyperaldosteronism leading to hypertension
  • Edema associated with liver cirrhosis, congestive cardiac failure and CKD
  • Reduced mortality in post-MI patients.

Use in cirrhosis
  • Patients with liver cirrhosis have reduced effective blood volume due to blood accumulation in the splanchnic vessels due to vasodilatation. This results in activation of RAAS and retention of salt and water - Ascites and resistance to loop diuretics.
  • Aldosterone enters the cells in the late DCT and Collecting ducts via diffusion and binds to specific mineralocorticoid receptors in the cellular cytosol, which mediates sodium reabsorption and potassium and H+ secretion into the tubules.
  • Eplerenone competitively blocks this MR receptor, resulting in natriuresis.

Side effects
  • Hyperkalemia
  • No anti-androgenic effects seen

questions.text: A 57-year-old man was brought to the hospital with complaints of dizziness and breathlessness. During the physical examination, his face appears to be discoloured. His current medication includes Amiodarone, Metoprolol, Verapamil, Lisinopril and Amlodipine. Which of the following drugs is responsible for these skin changes?
questions.explanation:
Amiodarone

MOA 
  • Prolonged action potential duration and QT interval by blocking delayed rectifier K+ channels.
  • Blocks inactivated Na+ channels, with rapid channel recovery (Decrease phase 0 slope).
  • Partially inhibits myocardial Ca2+ channels, adding to its antiarrhythmic effects.
  • Used to treat both atrial and ventricular fibrillation

Uses

To maintain normal sinus rhythm during atrial fibrillation and prevent recurrent ventricular tachycardia.

Adverse effects
  • Hypotension and Bradycardia (with i.v administration or after drug accumulation)
  • Photosensitivity: Skin pigmentation - Purple colour (purple man syndrome, smurf syndrome)
  • Corneal microdeposits: Reversible upon drug discontinuation.
  • Pulmonary alveolitis and fibrosis (On long-term use)
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Thyroid Dysfunction: Interfere with thyroid function as it acts as a source of iodine and can potentially lead to goitre, hypothyroidism (Wolf Chaikoff effect), or, in rare cases, hyperthyroidism (Jos-Basedow effect).

Interactions
  • Inhibits CYP3A4, CYP2C9, and P-glycoprotein, leading to potential interactions with drugs metabolized by this system.
  • Increases plasma levels of digoxin and warfarin.
  • Additive AV block with beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers.

questions.text: A breast cancer patient post-chemotherapy developed a low-grade fever with anemia and leukocytopenia (<4000/cm3; DNC: 30). Which of the following antibiotics will not be used in the empirical management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Linezolid

MOA

Protein synthesis inhibitor of the class oxazolidinones

  • Attaches to a site on the bacterial 23S ribosomal RNA of the 50S subunit
  • Prevents the formation of a functional 70S initiation complex.
  • It mainly acts against gram-positive organisms

Uses
  • Skin and skin structure infections by staphylococcus and streptococcus.
  • ﻿﻿Community-acquired pneumonia due to streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • ﻿﻿Nosocomial pneumonia due to staphylococcus aureus.

Adverse effects
  • Inhibits mitochondrial protein synthesis and may lead to
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Optic neuritis
  • Lactic acidosis in patients receiving the drug for longer durations.
  • ﻿﻿Serotonin syndrome when coadministered with adrenergic or serotonergic drugs like SSRIs due to its nonspecific MAO inhibition.
  • Linezolid can cause myelosuppression, which can present as
  • Anemia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Leukopenia
  • Sometimes pancytopenia.
  • It usually occurs 7-10 days after administration of the drug and is usually reversed on discontinuation of the drug.

questions.text: Which organism is most likely causing the infection in a 14-day-old neonate with bilateral conjunctivitis and lung infiltrates, as found in a chest X-ray performed at the outpatient department?
questions.explanation:
Definition

  • Ophthalmia neonatorum or neonatal conjunctivitis is a mucoid, mucopurulent, or purulent discharge from one or both eyes in the first month of life.
  • Any discharge, even watery, from a baby’s eyes in the first week of life must be viewed under suspicion as tears are not secreted so early in life.






 

Aetiology of ophthalmia neonatorum

Mode of infection:

  • Before birth:
    • Very rare through infected liquor amnii
  • During birth:
    • From an infected birth canal
  • After birth:
    • During the first bath of a newborn
    • Soiled clothes
    • Fingers with infected lochia
 

Source of infection:

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae:
    • Transmitted at the time of delivery
    • Presents between 2-5 days of birth (Option B)
    • The discharge becomes mucopurulent and purulent quickly
    • Thick yellow pus and marked chemosis
    • Cornea seen at the bottom of a crater-like pit in severe cases
 
  • Chlamydia trachomatis:
    • Transmitted at the time of delivery
    • Onset at 5-14 days after birth (Option C)
    • Serotypes D to K are the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries
    • Characteristic intracellular inclusion bodies are seen
    • Less severe inflammation
    • Purulent discharge +
 
  • Other causes:
    • Staphylococci/ Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option A)
    • Gram-negative coliforms
    • Herpes simplex virus
    • Chemical: silver nitrate solution previously used for prophylaxis immediately after birth: erythema, chemosis, lid edema, and discharge within the first 24 hours after birth.
 

Prophylaxis

  • Antenatal measures:
    • Treatment of genital infections and care of mother
    • Surveillance of pregnant women for STDs
  • Natal measures:
    • Aseptic, sterile precautions to be followed during deliveries
    • Clean the infant’s closed lids with sterile cotton soaked in normal saline and dried
  • Post-natal measures:
    • Povidone-iodine 2.5% solution
    • If the mother is under suspicion, 1% tetracycline or 0.5% erythromycin eye ointment is used in the baby immediately after birth and watched for a week.
    • Ceftriaxone 50mg/kg IM or IV single dose for infants born to mothers with untreated gonococcal infection.
  • Crede’s method:
    • Old method using 1% silver nitrate applied to infants' eyes right after birth
    • It is NOT used now as it can cause chemical neonatal conjunctivitis.

Diagnosis

Treatment

Neisseria gonorrhoea

Ceftriaxone IM, gentamicin drops, bacitracin eye ointment

Chemical

Wash eyes, erythromycin ointment, observe

Other bacteria

Neomycin-bacitracin ointment, gentamicin, or tobramycin drops

Herpes simplex virus

Acyclovir 3% eye ointment, systemic acyclovir (systemic involvement)

Chlamydia trachomatis

Erythromycin or chlortetracycline eye ointment, oral erythromycin (systemic infection)

questions.text: Which of the following oil red O stain is used?
An electron microscopic picture of a cut section of a nerve fibre is given. Identify the area that will be affected by the most common variant of Guillain-Barre syndrome.
questions.explanation:
Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS)

A group of immune-mediated disorders causing acute paralysis, clinically characterized by weakness starting in the distal limbs and quickly progressing to involve proximal muscle function, resulting in "ascending paralysis”.

Variants

Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP)

  • The most common variant is in Europe & North America.
  • Patchy segmental demyelination of spinal cord and peripheral nerves
  • Antibodies seen:
  • IgG Anti GM1
  • IgG Anti GQ1b

 

Axonal Variants

  • Often associated with Campylobacter jejuni infection.
  • More prevalent in China and Japan.

 

Miller Fisher Syndrome

  • Best-recognised variant.
  • Associated with anti-GQ1b antibodies.
  • Presents with internal and external ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and areflexia

Clinical features

Motor Symptoms:

  • Progressive ascending paralysis (distal to proximal)
  • Areflexia
  • Weakness in legs causing rubbery legs and instability to stand
  • Truncal paralysis, quadriplegia, neck floppiness
  • Bilateral 7th nerve palsy
  • Bulbar palsy
  • Difficulty in handling secretions leading to aspiration pneumonia
  • A leading cause of death due to pulmonary involvement.
  • Diaphragmatic paralysis
  • Ventilatory support is required in 30% of cases.
  • Increased carbon dioxide levels.

 

Sensory Symptoms:

  • Glove-and-stocking distribution paresthesias
  • Proprioception loss
  • Difficulty in climbing stairs
  • Pain in the neck/arm/shoulder is similar to over-exercised muscle
  • Sensory manifestations can occur before or along with motor manifestations.

 

Autonomic Symptoms:

  • Autonomic dysregulation (e.g., orthostatic hypotension, bladder/bowel sparing/transient involvement)
  • Wide fluctuations of blood pressure, arrhythmias, postural hypotension
  • Reduced heart rate and blood pressure, neurogenic shock.

Investigations

Lumbar Puncture

  • CSF protein: 100-1000 mg/dL
  • Elevated CSF protein but normal WBC count (albuminocytologic dissociation)

CSF Study Timing

  • Normal CSF findings (<48 hours)
  • Maximum rise of protein seen by 7 days

Electrodiagnostic Testing

  • Prolonged F-wave latencies
  • Earliest finding in AIDP (Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy)

                 Criteria

                            Description

   Flaccid Bilateral Weakness

Weakness of limbs (flaccid).

             Areflexia

Areflexia is present in areas of weakness.

CytoAlbuminologic dissociation

Elevated CSF protein with normal WBC count.

     Monophasic Illness

Symptoms develop over 12 hours to 28 days.

       Electrodiagnostic

Electrodiagnostic findings are consistent with demyelination.

questions.text: All of the following are associated with massive splenomegaly, except:
questions.explanation:
Aplastic Anemia

It refers to a syndrome of chronic primary hematopoietic failure and attendant pancytopenia.

Cause 

Acquired

  • Idiopathic
  • Acquired stem cell defects
  • Immune-mediated

Chemical agents

  • Dose-related (Alkylating agents, antimetabolites, benzene, chloramphenicol, inorganic arsenicals)
  • Idiosyncratic (Chloramphenicol, phenylbutazone, organic arsenicals, methylphenylethylhydantoin, carbamazepine, penicillamine, gold salts)

Physical agents

  • Whole-body irradiation
  • Viral infections
  • Hepatitis (unknown virus)
  • Cytomegalovirus infections
  • Epstein-Barr virus infections
  • Herpes zoster (varicella zoster)

Inherited

  • Fanconi anemia
  • Telomerase defects

Pathogenesis

The pathogenesis of aplastic anaemia is not fully understood. However, two major etiologies have been invoked:

  • Extrinsic (immune-mediated suppression of marrow progenitors)
  • Intrinsic (abnormality of stem cells)

Clinical features
  • Onset: Insidious.
  • Pancytopenia
  • Anaemia (progressive weakness, pallor, and dyspnea)
  • Thrombocytopenia (petechiae and ecchymoses)
  • Neutropenia (frequent and persistent infections or the sudden onset of chills, fever, and prostration).
  • Splenomegaly is absent (Option B)
  • The red cells are usually slightly macrocytic and normochromic.

Microscopy
  • Hypocellular bone marrow is largely devoid of hematopoietic cells; often, only fat cells, fibrous stroma, and scattered lymphocytes and plasma cells remain.
  • Marrow aspirates often yield little material (a “dry tap”).

options.text: Sudden cardiac death due to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

options.label: D
options.text: Sudden cardiac death due to atherosclerosis

questions.correct_answer: C. Sudden cardiac death due to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
questions.explanation:
Sudden Cardiac Death (SCD)

Sudden Cardiac Death (SCD) is defined as unexpected death occurring within an hour of symptom onset due to cardiac causes, including unwitnessed deaths in individuals who seemed healthy within the last 24 hours.

Risk Factors
  • Structural Heart Disease: The presence of structural heart issues or inherited arrhythmia syndromes significantly increases SCD risk.
  • Major Risk Factors:
  • Coronary Heart Disease (CHD)
  • Heart Failure
  • Diabetes
  • Hypertension
  • Smoking
  • Family History of SCD

 

In Athletes

  • Younger Athletes: The leading causes of SCD are inherited cardiac conditions, particularly Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM). (Option C)
  • Older Athletes: Risks are primarily associated with atherosclerotic coronary artery disease (CAD).

Precipitating Factors
  • SCD and Sudden Cardiac Arrest (SCA) frequently occur at specific times (e.g., mornings, winter months) and in public places.
  • Vigorous exertion, especially in men, can trigger SCD; however, regular exercise may reduce this risk.

Underlying Heart Disease
  • The most common cause of SCD is Ventricular fibrillation
  • Many SCD cases are linked to coronary artery disease (CAD), but non-ischemic cardiomyopathies and other heart conditions also contribute.
  • Common mechanisms leading to SCD include:
  • Acute Myocardial Infarction
  • Bradyarrhythmias
  • Ventricular scars leading to arrhythmias

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presented with intussusception and was taken up for surgery. He was found to have multiple polyps. The resected section was sent for histopathology, and the whole mount image of the specimen is given below. Identify the lesion.
questions.explanation:
Features

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS)

Juvenile polyposis syndrome (JPS)

Inheritance pattern

Autosomal dominant disorder

Autosomal dominant inheritance

Age

Presents around 11 years of age

Primarily affects children under 5 years old.

Features
  • Caused by a loss of function mutation in the STK11 gene 
  • Characterized by:
  • Gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps, especially in the small intestine
  • Mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation (macules on lips, nostrils, buccal mucosa, and extremities).
  • Polyps are large, pedunculated, and lobulated.
  • Can be sporadic or syndromic.
  • Sporadic: Single polyps.
  • Syndromic: 3-100 polyps.
  • Linked to mutations in the SMAD4 and BMPR1A genes, part of the TGF-β signalling pathway.
  • Pedunculated polyp, which is usually less than 3 cm in diameter.
  • Extra-intestinal manifestations include congenital malformations and digital clubbing. 
Microscopy

An arborizing pattern of smooth muscle and glands lined by normal epithelium.

Contains cystic spaces filled with mucin and inflammatory debris.

 

﻿Classification of Colorectal Polyps

Neoplastic Polyps

Non-Neoplastic Polyps

Adenomatous Polyps (Adenomas)

  • Tubular
  • Villous
  • Tubulovillous

Inflammatory Polyps

Associated with inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)

Serrated Polyps

  • Hyperplastic Polyps
  • Sessile Serrated Adenomas (SSA/Ps)
  • Traditional Serrated Adenomas (TSAs)

Hamartomatous Polyps

  • Juvenile Polyps: Usually in children, generally benign but associated with Juvenile Polyposis Syndrome.
  • Peutz-Jeghers Polyps: Associated with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, characterized by pigmentation around the mouth.

-

Lymphoid Polyps

It is composed of lymphoid tissue, usually benign and associated with the immune response

questions.text: Which of the following is used in treating sideroblastic anaemia?
questions.explanation:
Sideroblastic Anemia

It is a condition characterized by defective heme synthesis in the bone marrow, leading to the accumulation of iron within the mitochondria of red blood cell precursors (sideroblasts).

Causes
  • Congenital causes:  Due to enzyme deficiencies like ALA synthase, ferrochelatase, etc.
  • Acquired causes
  • Vitamin B6 deficiency
  • Drugs like isoniazid and chloramphenicol
  • Lead and alcohol poisoning

Pathogenesis
  • Vitamin B6 is crucial for the proper function of enzymes in heme synthesis.
  • As a cofactor for aminolevulinic acid synthase, it aids in the first step of heme production.
  • Ensuring sufficient vitamin B6 restores enzyme activity, supports heme synthesis, and helps alleviate symptoms of sideroblastic anaemia.

Microscopy

Peripheral Smear: Pappenheimer bodies

  • Multiple basophilic iron aggregates
  • Stain blue with Perl's/ Prussian blue
  • Seen in  sideroblastic anaemia, lead poisoning, or hemochromatosis

 

 

Bone Marrow: Ringed Sideroblasts

  • Blue granules form a full or partial ring
  • Blasts have a nucleus
  • Iron is present in mitochondria in the perinuclear region.
  • Stain blue on Perl's/Prussian blue.
  • Seen with Sideroblastic anemia and Myelodysplastic syndrome.
  • Associated with SF3B1 mutation

 

 

 

Vitamin B1 (Option C), or thiamine, plays a key role in carbohydrate metabolism and nerve function. Its deficiency causes conditions like Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome and Beriberi, but it is not linked to sideroblastic anaemia.

Vitamin B12 (Option A) deficiency causes megaloblastic anaemia and neurological symptoms. It results from poor diet, malabsorption, or lack of intrinsic factors. In sideroblastic anaemia, vitamin B6 is used instead of vitamin B12 because it helps correct the heme synthesis defect, while B12 is not involved in this process.

 

Iron (Option D) deficiency presents with symptoms like pale skin, shortness of breath, dizziness or lightheadedness, brittle nails, headaches, restless legs syndrome, etc. In sideroblastic anaemia, treatment focuses on addressing the underlying cause, as the main issue is impaired heme synthesis. Iron supplementation is generally ineffective and may worsen the condition by increasing iron accumulation in tissues.

questions.text: Which of the following mediators is involved in the early phase of type 1 hypersensitivity? Mast cell Histamine Neutrophils Prostaglandins Leukotrienes
questions.explanation:
Mast cells

Histamine

Prostaglandins

Leukotrienes

Primary effector cells.

Activated by allergens cross-linking with IgE antibodies.

Released by mast cells.

Causes vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, smooth muscle contraction, and mucus production.

They are lipid mediators released by mast cells.

Contribute to vasodilation, vascular permeability, and bronchoconstriction.

A group of lipid mediators released by mast cells.

Promote bronchoconstriction, increased vascular permeability, and the recruitment of other inflammatory cells.

 

Early phase reaction

Late phase reaction

Onset

Immediate (within minutes of allergen exposure).

Delayed (several hours after exposure) and can last for days.

Cells involved

Mast cells, basophils.

Eosinophils, T lymphocytes.

Cellular events

Activation of mast cells and basophils.

Recruitment and activation of leukocytes, especially eosinophils.

Mediators

Histamine, leukotrienes (LTB4, LTC4, LTD4), prostaglandins (PGD2) and Platelet-activating factor (PAF). 

Cytokines (e.g., IL-4, IL-5, TNF), chemokines (e.g., eotaxin)

Initiating event

Exposure to allergen triggers cross-linking of IgE on mast cells/basophils.

Recurrent inflammation, sustained by recruited leukocytes.

Effect on tissues

Vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, smooth muscle contraction.

Sustained inflammation and tissue damage due to leukocyte infiltration.

Clinical manifestations

Allergic rhinitis (hay fever), urticaria (hives), Angioedema bronchoconstriction.

Allergic asthma exacerbation, persistent inflammation, and tissue damage.

Therapeutic Approach

Antihistamines for symptomatic relief.

Adrenaline in anaphylactic shock

Broad-spectrum anti-inflammatory drugs (e.g., steroids) to suppress inflammation and prevent tissue damage.

questions.text: Which of the statements below accurately describes congenital CMV infection?

options.label: A
options.text: About 20-30% of the infections are symptomatic

options.label: B
options.text: Triad of SNHL, periventricular calcification and enamel hypoplasia

options.label: C
options.text: Most children asymptomatic at birth can develop conductive hearing loss later in life

options.label: D
options.text: If the mother is lgG positive for CMV, the child is unlikely to develop an infection

questions.correct_answer: D. If the mother is lgG positive for CMV, the child is unlikely to develop an infection
questions.explanation:
Human cytomegalovirus (CMV)

Mode of Transmission
  • Bodily fluids: saliva, urine, blood, vaginal fluids, breast milk
  • Community exposure: Daycare centres
  • Perinatal exposure: During birth
  • Breastfeeding

Risk of Transmission
  • 30% of women with primary CMV infection during pregnancy transmit the virus to the fetus.
  • In-utero infections also occur in previously immune women but at a reduced rate

Transmission by Gestational Age

Transmission rates are higher following a primary infection, with the risk increasing as gestational age advances.

Clinical Features of congenital CMV infection
  • Asymptomatic Infection (90% of infected newborns): No signs at birth; detected through newborn screening.
  • Symptomatic Infection (10% of infected newborns (vs Option A)):
    • Jaundice (direct bilirubin >2 mg/dL)
    • Petechiae (small, red, or purple spots on the skin) giving a blueberry muffin appearance
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Microcephaly
    • Intrauterine growth restriction
    • Chorioretinitis
    • Purpura (3% infants) (larger areas of bleeding under the skin)
  • Less Common Findings:
    • Hearing loss (M/c long-term consequence; may develop later).
  • Lab findings align with the clinical presentation: Direct hyperbilirubinemia, ￪ ALT, thrombocytopenia, and Head CT abnormalities

questions.explanation:
Mild Disease
  • Home Management & Hydration
  • Medications: Use paracetamol for fever and nasal saline drops for congestion.
  • Avoid antibiotics and multivitamins (no proven benefit).
  • Monitoring: Watch for red flag signs like rapid breathing, oxygen saturation below 95%, persistent fever, lethargy, or poor feeding.
 

Moderate Disease
  • Admit to Covid ward
  • SpO2 > 94: Hydration, paracetamol and antimicrobials
  • SpO2 < 94: Oxygen, IV Steroids, Remdesivir, Antimicrobials
 

Severe/Critical

  • Covid - 19 ICU / HDU ward
  • Oxygen, CPAP, Invasive ventilation if required
  • IV corticosteroids, Remdesivir (controversial) , Enoxaparin, Antimicrobials
  • Manage Shock, ARDS, AKI, and Myocarditis as per protocol

questions.text: A child presents with fever and vesicular lesions on the upper and lower limbs. Neck stiffness was present. Similar lesions were present on the palms, soles, and oral cavity. CSF analysis revealed normal glucose levels and elevated lymphocytes and protein. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease

questions.correct_answer: B. Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease
questions.explanation:
Hand Foot Mouth Disease (HFMD)

Causative organism

Coxsackie A16 virus and Enterovirus A71

Age group

<5 years

Clinical features
  • Low-grade fever, feeling of being unwell, and sore throat are commonly observed.
  • Characterized by papulovesicular skin rash commonly on buttocks, knees, elbows, around the mouth, and genital area.
  • Ulcers/blisters are also seen in the oral cavity, mostly on the posterior aspect
 

Management 
  • Resolves on its own in 5-7 days, till then symptomatic and conservative treatment is given.
  • Isolation of affected children at home and promotion of hand hygiene to prevent disease spread is important.

Terms

Definition

Twilight state
  • It refers to a state of disturbed consciousness along with hallucinations.

Oneiroid state or oneirophrenia
  • Dream-like delusional derangement of consciousness in which the patient is not fully oriented in time and place.
  • A characteristic feature of this state - is the presence of kaleidoscopic quality of the dream-like experiences where reality, illusions, and hallucinations are merged into one.
  • Associated with catatonic disturbances.

Oligophrenia
  • It refers to a group of mental states characterised by subnormal levels of intellectual activity.
  • Either congenital or acquired during early infancy.
  • Associated with other cognitive disturbances, affective disorders, and volitional disorders.

Paranoid ideation
  • Refers to thinking that is dominated by persecutory, suspicious, or grandiose content.
  • Thought content is less than that for delusions.
  • Paranoid delusions refer to persecutory delusions and delusions of grandeur, control, and reference.

questions.text: A young male who is shy and prefers social isolation appears to be emotionally cold and resides alone. There is no history of hallucinations or delusions. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Cluster A Personality Disorders

Characterised by odd and aloof behaviour, prone to develop psychosis.

Disorder

Key Features

Diagnosis

Treatment

Paranoid Personality Disorder (Option A)
  • Pervasive distrust and suspiciousness of others
  • Hostility, irritability, anger
  • Difficulty with trust and intimacy
  • Cynical view of the world
  • No fixed delusions (vs. delusional disorder)
  • No hallucinations or formal thought disorder (vs. schizophrenia)
  • No tumultuous relationships (vs. borderline personality disorder)
  • No history of antisocial behaviour (vs. antisocial personality disorder)
  • Psychotherapy: Straightforward and honest therapist, avoid warmth or deep interpretation
  • Group therapy: Helpful for some, but poorly tolerated
  • Behavior therapy: Social skills training may feel intrusive

Schizoid Personality Disorder

(Option B)
  • Lifelong social withdrawal
  • Eccentric, isolated, and lonely
  • Introverted with a bland affect
  • No psychotic symptoms (vs. schizophrenia, delusional disorder)
  • More withdrawn and aloof (vs. paranoid personality disorder)
  • No dysphoric loneliness
  • Fewer past relationships, possible autistic reverie
  • No desire for social interaction (vs. avoidant personality disorder)
  • Psychotherapy: Build trust, encourage expression
  • Group therapy: May benefit, initial silence likely
  • Pharmacotherapy: Limited evidence, medications for specific symptoms (e.g., emotional detachment)

Schizotypal Personality Disorder

  • Social difficulties
  • Eccentric behaviour and thinking (“magical thinking”)
  • Peculiar speech, superstitious beliefs, perceptual illusions
  • Odd behaviour, thinking, and perception (vs. schizoid and avoidant personality disorders)
  • Differentiated from autism by the severity of language disorder
  • Lacks psychosis, or it's brief (vs. schizophrenia)
  • No odd behaviour (vs. paranoid personality disorder)
  • Psychotherapy: Sensitive approach to avoid ridicule
  • Antipsychotics: Manage illusions and odd ideas
  • Antidepressants: Used for depressive symptoms

questions.text: Among the following, what is the most common symptom of adult obsessive-compulsive disorder?
questions.explanation:
Clinical presentation of OCD

Contamination is the most common presentation.

  • An obsession with contamination followed by washing and avoiding the presumably contaminated object.

Pathological doubt is the second most common presentation

  • Obsession of doubt, usually followed by compulsion of checking.

Intrusive/forbidden thoughts are the third most common presentation.

  • Obsessed with intrusive thoughts of aggressive or sexual acts without a compulsion.

Symmetry/ordering is the fourth most common presentation.

  • The patient needs symmetry/precision, which results in the compulsion of slowness.

Clinical presentation

Contamination / Cleansing

Most common presentation.

Pathological doubt /checking

Second most common presentation

Intrusive/forbidden thoughts

Third most common presentation.

Symmetry/ordering

Fourth most common presentation.

Uses

  • Generalised anxiety disorder (GAD)
  • Social anxiety disorder (SAD)

Side effects

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects is the least probable in a patient prescribed with escitalopram?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) are a class of drugs primarily used to treat depression and other mental health conditions. They increase serotonin levels in the brain, which helps regulate mood, emotion, and sleep.

Common SSRIs
  • Sertraline
  • Fluoxetine
  • Paroxetine
  • Citalopram
  • Escitalopram
  • Vilazodone (SPARI- Serotonin Partial Agonist and Reuptake Inhibitor)
  • Fluvoxamine (mainly for OCD)

Side Effects

Gastrointestinal

  • Nausea (most common) (Option A)
  • Diarrhea
  • Anorexia
  • Dry mouth
  • Weight gain
  • Constipation (especially with paroxetine)

CNS

  • Anxiety
  • Insomnia
  • Sedation
  • Vivid dreams (Option B)
  • Emotional blunting
  • Seizures (rare)
  • Extrapyramidal symptoms

Sexual Dysfunction

(most common side effect in long-term use)
  • Decreased libido
  • Delayed ejaculation
  • Inhibited orgasm (Option C)

Haematological

  • Impaired platelet aggregation
  • Increased risk of GI bleeding (especially with NSAIDs)

Miscellaneous

  • Hyponatremia
  • Allergic rashes
  • Hyperprolactinemia (leading to galactorrhea or menstrual irregularities)

A 68-year-old male presents with palpitations and shortness of breath. His medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, and coronary artery disease. On examination, irregularly irregular heartbeats are noted. An electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals irregularly irregular rhythm , no P waves, and absence of an isoelectric baseline. His blood pressure is 132/84 mmHg, heart rate 130 bpm, and oxygen saturation 94% on room air. Given the patient's clinical presentation and history, which of the following treatment options should be considered as a first-line approach for managing this case?
questions.explanation:
Atrial Fibrillation

Features
  • Characterized by abnormal automatic firing and multiple re-entry circuits.
  • Atria beat rapidly and ineffectively; ventricles activated irregularly
  • Produces an "irregularly irregular" pulse
  • Palpitations, syncope, and breathlessness can be present
  • Asymptomatic AF: Can present as systemic embolism and stroke

ECG Features
  • QRS Complexes: Irregular but normal
  • P Waves: Absent; baseline may show irregular fibrillation waves
  • Ventricular Rate:
    • Fast at onset (120-160 beats/min)
    • Slower in chronic AF due to medication effects and AV nodal fatigue

Management

Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation

  • First-line Therapy: Beta-blockers are effective in patients with CAD, hypertension, and heart failure. 
  • Class Ic Drugs: Propafenone or flecainide to prevent episodes (not for patients with CAD or LV dysfunction).
  • Class III Drugs:
    • Amiodarone: Most effective but with significant side effects; used when other treatments fail. (Option A)
    • Dronedarone: Alternative to amiodarone; contraindicated in heart failure.
  • Rate Control: Digoxin and verapamil for AV node conduction slowing, but not for AF prevention. 
  • Catheter Ablation: Considered for patients with drug-resistant AF; prevents AF in ~75% of cases but may have complications.

Persistent Atrial Fibrillation

  • Rhythm Control:
    • Cardioversion: Electrical or pharmacological (e.g., intravenous flecainide or amiodarone).
    • Timing: Immediate if AF <48 hours in unstable patients. (Option C)
    • Anticoagulation is required if AF ≥48 hours to prevent thromboembolic events. (Option D)
    • Prophylactic Amiodarone: To reduce recurrence risk.
  • Rate Control:
    • Medications: Digoxin, β-blockers, or rate-limiting calcium antagonists (verapamil, diltiazem).
    • Combination Therapy: Digoxin with β-blockers; avoid combining calcium antagonists with β-blockers.
    • Pace and Ablate: Permanent pacemaker with AV nodal block for symptomatic AF.

    • Anticoagulation is required if AF ≥48 hours to prevent thromboembolic events. 
    • Prophylactic Amiodarone: To reduce recurrence risk.
  • Rate Control:
    • Medications: Digoxin, β-blockers, or rate-limiting calcium antagonists (verapamil, diltiazem).
    • Combination Therapy: Digoxin with β-blockers; avoid combining calcium antagonists with β-blockers.
    • Pace and Ablate: Permanent pacemaker with AV nodal block for symptomatic AF.
 

Thromboprophylaxis:

  • Anticoagulation: Required for ischemic stroke prevention due to blood stasis in the left atrium. (2)
    • Warfarin: INR target of 2.0–3.0; start 4 weeks prior to cardioversion.
    • DOACs/NOACs: Rivaroxaban, apixaban, edoxaban, and dabigatran as alternatives to warfarin; no monitoring needed; contraindicated in atrial fibrillation with rheumatic mitral stenosis (1) or mechanical heart valves due to insufficient evidence supporting their safety and efficacy in these conditions. (3)
  • Risk Assessment:
    • CHA2DS2-VASc Score: For stroke risk; anticoagulate if score ≥2. 
    • HAS-BLED Score: For bleeding risk; monitor patients with score ≥3.
  • Aspirin: Not recommended due to low efficacy in preventing embolic stroke.

questions.text: A 60 year old male patient with critical mitral stenosis presented with atrial fibrillation. He has a history of multiple episodes of transient ischemic attacks. Which of the following are true regarding the prevention of stroke in this patient? Only aspirin is given Warfarin is given Direct oral anticoagulants are not indicated Mitral valvotomy should be recommended
questions.explanation:
Atrial Fibrillation

Features
  • Characterized by abnormal automatic firing and multiple re-entry circuits.
  • Atria beat rapidly and ineffectively; ventricles activated irregularly
  • Produces an "irregularly irregular" pulse
  • Palpitations, syncope, and breathlessness can be present
  • Asymptomatic AF: Can present as systemic embolism and stroke
ECG Features
  • QRS Complexes: Irregular but normal
  • P Waves: Absent; baseline may show irregular fibrillation waves
  • Ventricular Rate:
    • Fast at onset (120-160 beats/min)
    • Slower in chronic AF due to medication effects and AV nodal fatigue

Management

Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation:

  • First-line Therapy: Beta-blockers are effective in patients with CAD, hypertension, and heart failure. 
  • Class Ic Drugs: Propafenone or flecainide to prevent episodes (not for patients with CAD or LV dysfunction).
  • Class III Drugs:
    • Amiodarone: Most effective but with significant side effects; used when other treatments fail. 
    • Dronedarone: Alternative to amiodarone; contraindicated in heart failure.
  • Rate Control: Digoxin and verapamil for AV node conduction slowing, but not for AF prevention. 
  • Catheter Ablation: Considered for patients with drug-resistant AF; prevents AF in ~75% of cases but may have complications.
 

Persistent Atrial Fibrillation:

  • Rhythm Control:
    • Cardioversion: Electrical or pharmacological (e.g., intravenous flecainide or amiodarone).
    • Timing: Immediate if AF <48 hours in unstable patients. 
    • Anticoagulation is required if AF ≥48 hours to prevent thromboembolic events. 
    • Prophylactic Amiodarone: To reduce recurrence risk.
  • Rate Control:
    • Medications: Digoxin, β-blockers, or rate-limiting calcium antagonists (verapamil, diltiazem).
    • Combination Therapy: Digoxin with β-blockers; avoid combining calcium antagonists with β-blockers.
    • Pace and Ablate: Permanent pacemaker with AV nodal block for symptomatic AF.
 

Thromboprophylaxis:

  • Anticoagulation: Required for ischemic stroke prevention due to blood stasis in the left atrium. 
    • Warfarin: INR target of 2.0–3.0; start 4 weeks prior to cardioversion; recommended in patients with moderate to severe mitral stenosis or mechanical valves. (2)
    • DOACs/NOACs: Rivaroxaban, apixaban, edoxaban, and dabigatran as alternatives to warfarin; no monitoring needed; contraindicated in atrial fibrillation with rheumatic mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves due to insufficient evidence supporting their safety and efficacy in these conditions. (3)
  • Risk Assessment:
    • CHA2DS2-VASc Score: For stroke risk; anticoagulate if score ≥2. 
    • HAS-BLED Score: For bleeding risk; monitor patients with score ≥3.
  • Aspirin: Not recommended due to low efficacy in preventing embolic stroke. (1)

a wave (Option A ruled out)

Identify the organism shown in this image
questions.explanation:
Roundworm (Ascaris lumbricoides)

Habitat

Adult worms reside in the small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum) and are the largest nematode parasites in humans.

Morphology
 

Adult Worms: Large, cylindrical, with tapering ends and pale pink color that turns white outside the body.

Male Worms:

  • Smaller than females (15-30 cm long, 2-4 mm thick)
  • A ventrally curved posterior end and two copulatory spicules.

Female Worms:

  • Larger than males
  • Straight, conical posterior end (Option C) & a vulvar groove aiding in mating.

Reproduction

A single female can lay up to 200,000 eggs daily, which are expelled in the feces.

Host

Humans only

Infective Form

Embryonated eggs with L2 larvae.

Transmission

Ingestion of eggs from contaminated soil, food, or water.

questions.text: What is the underlying factor responsible for inducing aplastic crisis in individuals with hereditary spherocytosis?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Manifestations of Parvovirus infections:
 
 
  • Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease)
    • Children: "Slapped cheek" facial rash.
    • Adult women: Symmetrical polyarthropathy, often in hand and knee joints.
  • Transient Aplastic Crisis (Option D):
    • Severe acute anemia in patients with pre-existing hemolytic anemia.
  • Pure Red Cell Aplasia:
    • Chronic anemia in immunocompromised individuals due to persistent B19 infection.
  • Non-Immune Hydrops Fetalis:
    • Fatal fetal anemia and death; occurs via transplacental transmission (30% of cases)
    • Highest risk in the second trimester.
  • Papular-Purpuric Gloves and Socks Syndrome:
    • Painful, itchy, and symmetric swelling and erythema of distal hands and feet; may mimic acute meningococcemia.

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • PCR: Highly sensitive, detects viral DNA (VP1, VP2 genes) in serum, tissue, or respiratory secretions.
  • ELISA: Detects IgM antibody (early indicator, elevated 2–3 months) and IgG against VP1 and VP2 antigens.
  • Immunohistochemistry: Detects viral antigens in fetal tissues and bone marrow.
  • Bone marrow cytology shows Giant pro-erythroblasts with multiple cytoplasmic projections that look like "dog ears" or "pseudopodia".

questions.text: A man presents with the following lesion after traumatic inoculation. Identify the causative organism.
questions.explanation:
Sporotrichosis

Causative agent

Dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.

Epidemiology

Common in gardeners, forest workers, and manual labourers.

Route of transmission

Minor trauma or thorn prick.

Clinical features
  • Chronic infection affects cutaneous, subcutaneous, and lymphatic tissue.
  • Lesions form at sites of minor trauma or thorn pricks, starting as nodules.
  • Nodules ulcerate and necrose; infection spreads through lymphatic channels.

Lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis: Secondary ulcers on lymph nodes; lymphatics become hardened and cord-like.

Systemic dissemination: Can affect bones, joints, and meninges.

Specimens

Aspiration from nodules and biopsy material.

Diagnosis

 

Microscopy:

  • KOH mounts or histopathological sections stained by methenamine silver stain show asteroid bodies (Splendore hoeppli phenomenon)
  • Yeast phase: Cigar-shaped cells.

Culture: Thin septate hyphae with flower-like clusters of small conidia; pear-shaped conidia in rosette-like clusters in mycelial phase.

 

Serological tests: Helpful for extracutaneous or systemic infections.

Treatment

 

Medications:

  • Itraconazole
  • Terbinafine
  • Amphotericin B: For disseminated infection

Cryotherapy.

Agent

Japanese Encephalitis Virus (JEV), Group B Arbovirus

Virus Family: Flaviviridae

Transmission Vector

Culex mosquitoes (Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui)
 

Hosts

Pigs (Amplifier Host)

Ardeid Birds: Pond herons, Ducks, Poultry (Maintenance Host)

Man: (Accidental or dead-end host)

  • Do not develop high enough viremia to infect mosquitoes.
  • Primarily children (below 15 years), but all ages susceptible
  • No man-to-man transmission.

Horses: Only animals that can manifest symptoms (Option D).

Environmental Factors

Geographic Distribution:

  • Southeast Asia, East Asia, and the Western Pacific regions.
  • India
    • Endemic: To 21 states but mainly includes Jharkhand, Bihar, West Bengal, Uttar Pradesh, Assam and Haryana
  • Seasonal Distribution:
    • Monsoon and post-monsoon period (varies by region)

Adenoid Hypertrophy: (Enlargement of the adenoids)

Aetiology
  • Physiological Enlargement: Common in childhood.
  • Chronic Conditions: Recurrent rhinitis, sinusitis, chronic tonsillitis, & allergies.

Clinical Features
  • Nasal Symptoms:
  • Nasal obstruction leading to mouth breathing and feeding difficulties.
  • Nasal discharge due to choanal obstruction and chronic rhinitis.
  • Sinusitis, Epistaxis & voice changes due to nasal obstruction. (Rhinolalia clausa)
  • Aural Symptoms:
  • Tubal obstruction causing retracted tympanic membrane and CHL.
  • Recurrent acute otitis media and chronic suppurative otitis media.
  • Otitis media with effusion due to intermittent eustachian tube obstruction.
  • Adenoid Facies: Characteristic facial appearance with an elongated face, open mouth, crowded upper teeth, and high-arched palate.
 
  • Pulmonary Hypertension: Potential due to long-standing nasal obstruction.
  • Aprosexia: Difficulty concentrating

Clinical Examination
  • External Nose: Check for skin changes indicating frequent nose rubbing.
  • Nasal Assessment: Halogen light otoscope is used for simple anterior rhinoscopy, which examines the nasal cavity but not the adenoids.
  • Adenoid Assessment:
    • Nasendoscopy: For detailed evaluation, a flexible pediatric endoscope with topical anaesthesia is preferred. It provides an accurate assessment of adenoid size in an outpatient setting.
    • Lateral Soft-Tissue Radiograph: This is useful when endoscopy is not tolerated; it correlates well with endoscopic findings.

questions.text: Which of the following is not employed in post-laryngectomy rehabilitation?

What would be your diagnosis for a patient who has presented with symptoms of vertigo, tinnitus, and fullness of ears. The symptoms improve on keeping the right ear up. He had previously been operated on for a safe type of right side chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) six months ago?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Etiology

Can occur after head trauma, barotrauma (e.g., diving), temporal bone anomalies, or ear surgery (e.g., stapedectomy).

Symptoms

Fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, vertigo, tinnitus, and sometimes a sense of fullness in the ear.

Complications

Recurrent meningitis (especially in children with temporal bone defects), cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leak.

Diagnosis

Often clinical, based on history and symptoms; confirmed through surgical exploration if suspected.

Temporal bone CT: Shows pneumolabyrinth, accumulation of fluid in the middle ear, and/or ossicular chain disruption, but also can often be normal.

Treatment

Surgical closure of the fistula to prevent further complications, such as meningitis; limited improvement in hearing.

Prognosis

Hearing improvement post-surgery is usually limited; however, vertigo symptoms often improve or resolve.

questions.text: What is the nerve blocked in the following local anaesthesia technique?
questions.explanation:
Nerve Block

Anatomy

Anesthesia Distribution

Technique

Supraorbital & Supratrochlear (Ophthalmic Nerve)

Supraorbital nerve exits the supraorbital foramen on the superior surface of the orbital rim.

Supratrochlear exits medially at the orbital rim.

Anesthetizes the entire forehead up to the scalp's vertex.

Inject anesthetic subcutaneously above the eyebrow, from midline to the lateral orbit.

Infraorbital (Maxillary Nerve) 

 

Exits infraorbital foramen below the optic rim near the first maxillary premolar.

Provides sensation loss to lower eyelid, medial cheek, side of nose, upper lip.

Retract mucosa, insert needle above the first premolar, and inject 3-5 ml between cheek and gingiva.

Mental (Mandibular Nerve)

 

Mental nerve exits the mental foramen, a branch of the inferior alveolar nerve.

Anesthetizes lower lip, labial mucosa, and gingiva near incisors and canines.

Retract lip, insert needle near first/second premolars, and inject 3-5 ml in the mucosal fold

Inferior Alveolar (Mandibular Nerve) 

Arises from mandibular division of trigeminal (V3); landmarks: Mandibular sulcus, coronoid notch, pterygomandibular raphe.

Anesthetizes all lower teeth, gums, anterior labial and lingual areas.

Insert needle into pterygomandibular raphe, tap bone, withdraw slightly, and inject 2-3 ml.

Phase I

Dead Space Ventilation

◦ No gas exchange occurs here

(Option C)

Phase II

• CO₂ from alveoli reaches upper airway ,mixes with dead space air

• Causes  rapid rise in CO₂ concentration.

(Option B )

Phase III

Alveolar Plateau 

• Majority of exhaled air is CO₂-rich

End-Tidal

• This is the value you see on the monitor

(Option A )

Descending Phase

questions.text: Which of the following can be used for induction of anesthesia, maintenance and can be safely used in endotracheal intubation?
questions.explanation:
Sevoflurane

Properties

Sevoflurane is a fluorinated ether with low blood solubility (λb/g 0.65), allowing for rapid induction and emergence.

Its non-pungency makes it suitable for inhalation induction, especially in pediatric patients. It is used with conventional vaporizers.

Uses

Ideal for smooth and rapid inhalation induction, particularly in daycare procedures (4-8% concentration with nitrous oxide and oxygen).

It is commonly used for both pediatric and adult anesthesia.

C/I

Should be avoided in cases of severe hypovolemia, susceptibility to malignant hyperthermia, and intracranial hypertension.

Systemic Effects

Cardiovascular

Mild myocardial depression with slight reduction in systemic vascular resistance and blood pressure. It causes minimal heart rate increase and may prolong the QT interval.

Hepatic

Decreases portal vein flow but increases hepatic artery flow, maintaining overall hepatic perfusion.

Renal

Slightly decreases renal blood flow but has no known association with significant renal toxicity.

Compound A, a degradation product of sevoflurane, is nephrotoxic in animals but has no known adverse effects on humans.

Neuromuscular

Provides adequate muscle relaxation for intubation but is often combined with other agents or muscle relaxants.

Cerebral

Slight increases in cerebral blood flow (CBF) and intracranial pressure. High concentrations may impair CBF autoregulation. Seizures have not been reported.

Respiratory

Depresses respiration and helps reverse bronchospasm. Thus agent of choice in asthmatics.

questions.text: During resuscitation, a patient received a 20% intralipid injection. What could have been the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Features

CNS effects:

  • Early and less severe.
  • First symptom: circumoral paraesthesia
  • First sign: nystagmus
  • At low plasma concentration: mild sensory disturbances.
  • Increased concentration: CNS excitation, seizure activity.
  • Higher concentration: CNS depression, coma, respiratory depression, arrest.

Cardiac effects:

  • Usually late but severe form of toxicity, may lead to death.
  • Hypotension, dysrhythmias, myocardial depression.
  • Potent agents (bupivacaine, ropivacaine, levobupivacaine) linked to cardiovascular collapse, heart block.

Safety profile

Bupivacaine has more risk to cause LAST than Lidocaine

Most potent highly lipid soluble drugs are more likely to cause

Prevention
  • Risk recognition and dose reduction.
  • Careful aspiration before injection.
  • Incremental administration (3-5 mL) with continuous heart rate monitoring.
  • Use ultrasonographic guidance to confirm anesthetic deposit.
  • Use a vasoactive agent like epinephrine to reduce systemic absorption and serve as an intravascular indicator.

Treatment
  • Recognize LAST (Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity) early and call for help.
  • Airway management: Secure airway, ventilate with 100% oxygen.
  • Administer 20% Lipid Emulsion:
    • Bolus: 12 mL/kg over 2-3 min.
    • Infusion: at 0.25 mL/kg/min-0.5ml/kg/min for 15-20 mins
    • Maximum initial dose: 12 ml/kg
  • Administration of antiepileptics: for seizure control, benzodiazepines such as Lorazepam is preferred.
  • Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: if necessary, monitor the patient at least for initial 2-6 hours following resuscitation.

Pharmacological Agent

Mechanism of Action

Bisphosphonates (Alendronate, Risedronate, Ibandronate)

Interfere with osteoclast activity, leading to decreased bone resorption.

Calcitonin

Inhibits osteoclast activity, reducing bone resorption.

Denosumab

It inhibits the RANK ligand, essential for osteoclast formation and function.

Estrogen/Raloxifene

Inhibit osteoclast activity and slow bone loss.

Cinacalcet

Indirectly reduces bone resorption by lowering PTH levels.

Teriparatide

A recombinant form of PTH stimulates osteoblast activity.

Strontium Ranelate

Dual action: It promotes bone formation by stimulating osteoblasts and decreases bone resorption by inhibiting osteoclast activity.

questions.text: Match the following with their most appropriate mode of management: 1. Osteosarcoma 2. Simple bone cyst 3. Giant cell tumor 4. Osteoid osteoma A. Wide excision B. Curettage C. Radiofrequency ablation D. Intralesional steroid
questions.explanation:
Condition

Features and Findings

Treatment

Osteosarcoma
  • A malignant bone tumor, commonly affecting the metaphyses of long bones (e.g., femur, tibia).
  • It most frequently occurs in adolescents and young adults. Symptoms include pain, swelling, and sometimes a palpable mass.
  • X-rays typically show a sunburst appearance with mixed lytic and sclerotic areas.
  • Surgical resection (amputation or limb-sparing surgery), followed by chemotherapy.
  • Radiation therapy is rarely used.

Simple Bone Cyst

  • A benign, fluid-filled cyst, often occurring in the proximal humerus or femur.
  • It is typically asymptomatic
  • On X-ray, it appears as a well-defined, cystic lesion with a thin cortical rim.
  • Often occurs in children and adolescents.
  • Aspiration and steroid injection, or curettage with bone grafting if recurrent fractures occur.
  • Surgical intervention is usually necessary if there is risk of fracture.

Giant Cell Tumor

  • A benign, locally aggressive tumor that typically occurs in the epiphysis of long bones (e.g., distal femur, proximal tibia).
  • It is most common in young adults.
  • Symptoms include pain, swelling, and sometimes joint dysfunction.
  • X-rays show a lytic lesion with a "soap bubble" appearance.
  • Curettage with bone grafting or chemical adjuvants (e.g., phenol). Wide resection for larger or more aggressive tumors..

Osteoid Osteoma
  • A benign bone tumor that most commonly affects the femur or tibia. It typically occurs in adolescents or young adults.
  • Characterized by a small, well-circumscribed lesion with a central nidus on X-ray.
  • Symptoms include localized pain, especially at night, that is relieved by NSAIDs.
  • Surgical excision of the nidus is the standard treatment. Radiofrequency ablation can be used
  • Pain is often well-controlled with NSAIDs until definitive treatment.

questions.text: What fixative is used for a pap smear?
questions.explanation:
Pap smear

Site
  • Transformation zone of the cervix, where the squamous epithelium (ectocervix) and columnar epithelium (endocervix) meet.
  • This is the most common site for cervical cancer to develop.

Instruments
  • Ayre spatula collects cells from the ectocervix
  • Cervical broom (also called a cytobrush) from the transition zone
  • Endocervical brush from endocervix

Procedure
  • Conventional Pap smear:
    • Step 1: Insert a posterior vaginal wall retractor or speculum to expose the cervix for clear visibility and access.
    • Step 2: Use a small brush or spatula to collect cervical cells by gently rotating the instrument.
    • Step 3: Smear the collected cells onto a microscope slide, ensuring preservation of cell structure.
    • Step 4: Fix the smear with a fixative (95% ethyl alcohol) to preserve the cells for subsequent lab analysis.
  • Liquid-based cytology: Cells are collected and then rinsed into a liquid fixative vial. This is considered more sensitive than the conventional Pap smear as it provides a more uniform distribution of cells.

Considerations
  • Sensitivity: A single Pap test has a sensitivity of 47-62% for detecting high-grade cervical lesions.
  • HPV co-testing: Combining the Pap smear with HPV DNA testing significantly improves screening accuracy.
  • Colposcopy: Colposcopy, with biopsy if indicated, is the gold standard for evaluating abnormal Pap results.

Indications
  • Cervical cancer screening: Routine screening for women aged 21-65 years, with the frequency and type of testing varying based on age and risk factors.
  • Evaluation of abnormal vaginal bleeding: While not a primary diagnostic tool, a Pap smear is performed as part of the workup, along with other tests.

Timing & Frequency
  • Age 21-29: Cytology (Pap smear) every 3 years.
  • Age 30-65: Co-testing (Pap smear + HPV testing) every 5 years.
  • >65: No further screening if they have had 3 consecutive negative cytology results or 2 consecutive negative co-test results and no history of high-grade precancerous lesions.
  • H/o of CIN 2 or higher: Annual screening for 20 years.
  • More frequent screening in HIV and Immunocompromised patients.

Contraindications

Avoided during menstruation. (Relative C/I)

A 32-year-old pregnant female is carrying monochorionic diamniotic twins. On ultrasound examination, there is evidence of polyhydramnios in one twin and oligohydramnios in the other. What is the most likely complication?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Description

Stage I

Polyhydramnios in the recipient twin (deepest vertical pocket ≥8 cm) and oligohydramnios in the donor twin (deepest vertical pocket ≤2 cm), with a visible bladder in the donor twin.

Stage II

Severe oligohydramnios in the donor twin with no visible bladder.

Stage III

Critically abnormal Doppler findings, such as absent/reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery, reversed flow in the ductus venosus, or pulsatile flow in the umbilical vein in one or both twins.

Stage IV

Presence of hydrops fetalis in one or both twins, indicating severe fetal compromise.

Stage V

Demise of one or both twins.

AFP or β-hCG may be elevated

± Elevated

Elevated

Combination of seminoma + NSGCT, prognosis depends on dominant component.

Leydig Cell Tumor (Sex Cord-Stromal)

Normal

Normal

Normal

May secrete testosterone, causes precocious puberty or gynecomastia.

Sertoli Cell Tumor (Sex Cord-Stromal)

Normal

Normal

Normal

Rare, usually hormonally silent, incidental finding.

questions.text: What is the primary reason for bladder outlet obstruction in male children?

Which of the following statements are true about colon cancer? 1. Right and left colon cancers can behave differently 2. Colon cancers can be hereditary 3. Colon cancer risk can be reduced by metformin 4. Colon cancers frequently metastasize to the liver
questions.explanation:
Statement

True/False

Explanation

1. Right and left colon cancers can behave differently.

True

Right-sided colon cancer (proximal) is more likely to present with anemia, occult bleeding, and larger polypoid tumors, while left-sided colon cancer (distal) presents with obstruction, hematochezia, and napkin-ring lesions.

2. Colon cancers can be hereditary.

True

Hereditary Nonpolyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC/Lynch Syndrome) and Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) are genetic syndromes associated with increased colon cancer risk.

3. Colon cancer risk can be reduced by metformin.

True

Studies suggest that metformin reduces insulin resistance and suppresses colorectal cancer cell proliferation, lowering the risk, especially in diabetic patients.

4. Colon cancers frequently metastasize to the liver.

True

The portal venous system drains the colon to the liver, making it the most common site of metastasis. Other common sites include lungs and peritoneum.

questions.text: A 40 year old woman presented with jaundice, fever, and abdominal pain. She is suspected to have cholangitis. Which of the following apart from abdominal pain makes up Reynold pentad? 1. Fever 2. Jaundice 3. Hypotension 4. Altered sensorium 5. Hematemesis 6. Melena
questions.explanation:
Cholangitis

Aetiology

Often due to obstruction in the biliary tree, leading to bacterial infection by organisms like Klebsiella, E. coli, Enterobacter, Pseudomonas, and Citrobacter species.

Symptoms
  • Charcot's triad - pain, jaundice, fever
  • Additional tenderness in the epigastrium and right hypochondrium is common.
  • Severe Form: Reynolds pentad - persistent pain, fever, jaundice, shock, and altered mental status
  • Indicates acute obstructive suppurative cholangitis.

Lab Findings
  • Elevated white blood cell count, bilirubin, and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Chronic cases may show lobar or segmental atrophy or hypertrophy.

Recurrent Pyogenic Cholangitis
  • More common in East Asian populations, caused by intrahepatic stones and infections
  • Risk factors include parasitic infections like Clonorchis sinensis and Ascaris lumbricoides.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient undergoes a mastectomy for breast cancer. Post-operatively, the surgeon decides to use a closed suction drain. Which of the following drain types is shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Penrose drain (Option A)

This is an open, passive drain consisting of a soft rubber tube. It relies on gravity and capillary action for drainage.

Jackson-pratt drain (Option B)

Consists of a soft, flattened silicone tube connected to a soft plastic bulb

The bulb can be compressed to create negative pressure

Suitable for various surgeries, including breast, plastic, and abdominal procedures

Romovac suction drain (Option C)

Another type of closed suction drain

Uses a spring-loaded mechanism to create constant negative pressure

Often used in orthopedic surgeries and joint replacements

Hemovac drain (Option D)

This is another brand of closed suction drain, similar in principle to the JP drain. However, Hemovac drains typically have a larger, more rigid collection chamber compared to the soft, compressible bulb of the JP

questions.text: Which of the following statements about hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is/are correct? 1. TACE(Transarterial chemoembolization) is used for multinodular lesions 2. Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm 3. The incidence of HCC is increasing 4. NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC
questions.explanation:
Statement

True/False

Explanation

1. TACE (Transarterial Chemoembolization) is used for multinodular lesions.

True

TACE is used in intermediate-stage (BCLC B) HCC with multiple nodules and preserved liver function (Child-Pugh A/B).

2. Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm.

False

Lenvatinib is a systemic therapy for advanced HCC (BCLC C). Small (<3 cm) tumors are treated with resection, RFA, or liver transplant.

3. The incidence of HCC is increasing.

True

The incidence of HCC is rising globally due to increased metabolic syndrome, NAFLD/NASH, obesity, and hepatitis B/C.

4. NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC.

True

NAFLD/NASH are leading non-viral causes of HCC. They can cause HCC even in non-cirrhotic livers due to chronic inflammation.

questions.text: What is the most helpful test to identify the underlying cause in a 56-year-old patient with obstructive jaundice, who presents with a distended gall bladder, dilated common bile duct, and enlarged intrahepatic biliary radicles on ultrasound?
questions.explanation:
INVESTIGATIONS - CHOLEDOCHAL CYST

Endoscopic Ultrasound

(Option B ruled out)
  • The first imaging test that is performed.
  • Confirms the presence of the cyst.
  • Reveals anatomical details, including bile duct and pancreatic duct relationship.

Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)
  • Non-invasive imaging technique. Provides detailed images of the gallbladder and biliary system.
  • Highly sensitive (>90%) and specific (>99%) for identifying common bile duct stones.
  • Visualizes biliary anatomy and the extent of dilatation.

Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP):

(Option D ruled out)
  • Invasive procedure with endoscope and contrast material.
  • Diagnostic and therapeutic capabilities (tissue sampling, decompression, treatment of choledocholithiasis).
  • Effective but has a complication rate of up to 10%.

Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography (PTC)
  • Invasive procedure with a needle directly into the liver.
  • Useful for intrahepatic biliary disease or when ERCP is not feasible. (Option C ruled out)
  • Helps delineate surgical anatomy and enables drainage catheter and stent placement.

CT SCAN

Mainly to see the intrahepatic biliary system

Other Tests
  • Hepatobiliary nuclide Scanning
  • Liver Function Tests
